Eastern Montana is fairly dry at the best of times and these are not the best of times.
Drought has made life even harder on people who need water for their livelihoods.
This makes Roger Muggli an important man in his community.
Muggli runs the Tongue and Yellowstone Irrigation District near Miles City, Montana.
He determines how much water is diverted out of the Tongue River and into a separate canal used by farmers, ranchers and homeowners for irrigation.
As Muggli explained to independent producers Dan Collison and Elizabeth Meister, it's a challenging job.
We're standing at the 12-mile diversion dam on the on the Tongue River, 12 miles south of Miles City.

You open the head gates and close the head gates; it's like your valve or faucet in your kitchen sink, the more you open it the more water goes into the sink and in this case, into the canal, down into the valley some 27 miles away.
It's the lifeline.
It's the lifeline to my farm.
It's the lifeline to a lot of other farmers and gardeners.
And it's all part of our culture and part of our blood.
Water is more valuable than gold.
(Soundbite of running water)
Somebody said once that whiskey is made for drinking and water is made for fighting over.
It's absolutely the truth.
Five out of the last seven years have been really, really dry.
Of course, the drought has brought on a whole new gamut of problems, a lot of 100-degree days.

The water shortages are just immense, just from the standpoint of the land has to be irrigated more often and you have less water to go around, so that really hot weather really takes its toll on water volume.
You stand on the banks of your canal or whatever and there's hardly any water.
And you look out and see your crop withering before your eyes and you just feel like screaming.
You feel like beating up a fencepost.
